children.name: to use money to buy things
spend
children.definition: /spend/  to use money to buy things:
examples: tiêu, chi tiêu
▪ Everyone spends more at Christmas - it’s an important time for business.
▪ During the recession, even the tourists weren’t spending.
spend £5/$10/a dollar etc
▪ I bought two skirts and a T-shirt and I only spent $50.
spend on
▪ We spend about £85 a week on food.
▪ The government has promised to spend more money on education.
▪ She spends most of her salary on clothes.
spend money on doing something
▪ They spend quite a lot of money each week on eating out.

children.name: pay out
children.definition: /ˌpeɪ ˈaʊt/  to spend more money on something than you want to spend or more than you think is fair:
examples: ▪ £65! I don’t want to pay out that much!
pay out for
▪ You have to pay out so much money for car repairs these days.
pay out on
▪ The idea of paying out half my salary on rent didn’t sound too good.
pay out £5/$10 etc
▪ Did you know that Eddy paid out nearly £2000 for his new computer?

children.name: break into
children.definition: /ˈbreɪk ɪntuː/  to start spending an amount of money thatyou have savedor that youwere keepingfor a particular purpose before you really wanted to:
examples: ▪ We had to break into our savings to pay the hospital fees.
▪ I really want to avoid having to break into the money I was saving for college.

children.name: pay good money for
children.definition: /ˌpeɪ gʊd ˈmʌni fɔːʳ/ spokenuse this to talk about something you paid areasonableprice for, so you expect it to be of good quality or used properly so that your money hasnot been wasted:
examples: chi tiêu hợp lí
▪ I paid good money for that tennis racquet and it broke the first time I used it.
▪ What’s the point of paying good money for a wedding dress when I’m only going to wear it once?

children.name: pay
children.definition: /peɪ/  to spend £5, $10 etc on something because that iswhat it costs:
examples: ▪ Of course you have to pay more if you want to travel in the summer.
▪ What quality accommodation you get depends on how much you’re prepared to pay.pay for
▪ I like your new car - how much did you pay for it?pay £5/$10/a dollar etc for
▪ They paid over $100 each for tickets.
▪ The set meal costs £15 but you have to pay extra for wine.

children.name: thrifty
children.definition: /ˈθrɪfti/  spending money carefully and cleverly so that nothing is wasted and you can manage with the money you have:
examples: tiết kiệm
▪ Mrs Jones was a very thrifty woman who never wasted anything.
▪ By being thrifty and shopping wisely you can feed an entire family on as little as $100 a week.
thrift [uncountable noun]
▪ The old values of thrift being thrifty and hard work seem to be things of the past.

children.name: careful
children.definition: /ˈkeəʳfəl/  spending money only on things that are necessary or cheap because you want your money to last as long as possible:
examples: cẩn trọng ( chi tiêu )
▪ I wouldn’t say he was mean -- he’s just careful.
careful with money
▪ Once you’ve spent your allowance there won’t be any more. You must learn to be more careful with money.

children.name: economical
children.definition: /ˌekəˈnɒmɪkəl, ˌiː-ǁ-ˈnɑː-/  spending money carefully and sensibly so that you do not spend more than necessary:
examples: tiết kiệm
▪ I’m trying to be more economical when I go shopping, and only buying what I really need.
▪ Tim’s a very economical person,. He always looks around for the best buys.
economically [adverb]
▪ By shopping economically, you can save a lot of money on your weekly bill.

children.name: frugal
children.definition: /ˈfruːgəl/  spending as little money as possible,evenon things that arenecessarysuch as food and drink, especially because you arepoor:
examples: căn cơ, đạm bạc
▪ He was very frugal, and would often use a tea bag three or four times over.
▪ The monks lead a frugal life, allowing themselves only the bare essentials.
frugally [adverb]
▪ We moved to a little house in the country and tried to live as frugally as possible.

children.name: to spend a lot of money
spend a lot
children.definition: /ˌspend ə ˈlɒtǁ-ˈlɑːt/
examples: chi tiêu quá nhiều
▪ You don’t have to spend a lot to be fashionable -- you just need a sense of style.
spend a lot on
▪ They must have spent a lot on their new kitchen. It’s made of solid oaks
pend a lot of money
▪ In recent years the company has spent a lot of money on new technology.

children.name: splash out (sth)
children.definition: splash out(sth)phrasal verbUK
examples: to spend a lot of money on buying things, especially things which are pleasant to have but which you do not need
_They splashed out £3000ona holiday.

children.name: lay sth out
children.definition: laysthoutphrasal verbSPEND MONEY
examples: informalto spend money, especially a large amount
_It's not every day you lay out £2000ona holiday.

children.name: go to great expense
children.definition: /gəʊ tə ˌgreɪt ɪkˈspens/  to spend verylargeamounts of money on somethingimportant, even if it costs youmore thanyou can afford:
examples: chi một đống tiền ( nhiều hơn khả năng chi trả của bạn )
▪ The wedding was wonderful. Your parents obviously went to great expense.
go to great expense to do something
▪ Please let us have your comments on the plans for the new offices -- we’re going to great expense to get everything just right.

children.name: spare no expense
children.definition: /speəʳ ˌnəʊ ɪkˈspens/  to spend as much money as is necessary to get what you want or make something successful, without worrying about the cost:
examples: không ngại chi
▪ The organizers were told to spare no expense - this was going to be the biggest show on Earth.
no expense spared
▪ ‘Go out and buy whatever you want,’ he said, ‘no expense spared!’

children.name: shell out/fork out
children.definition: /ˌʃel ˈaʊt, ˌfɔːʳk ˈaʊt/ spokeninformaltohave tospend more money on something than you think isfairorreasonable:
examples: chi ( buộc phải )
▪ No, we can’t afford to go to the bowling alley - I’ve forked out enough already today.
shell out #50/$100 etc
▪ Insurance companies are having to shell out millions of pounds to the victims of the floods.
shell out/fork out on
▪ I’m not shelling out any more money on this old car. It’s not worth it!
shell out/fork out for
▪ I failed my driving test and Dad said that he wasn’t forking out for any more lessons for me.

children.name: go on a spending spree
children.definition: /ˌgəʊ ɒn ə ˈspendɪŋ ˌspriː/ informalto spend a lot of money and buy a lot of things in ashorttimefor enjoyment, especially when other people think this isstupidor awasteof money:
examples: vung tiền( trong 1 thời gian ngắn cho ăn chơi )
▪ Jilly and I decided to cheer ourselves up and go on a spending spree.
▪ You haven’t been on another spending spree, have you? What did you buy this time?

children.name: money is no object
children.definition: /ˌmʌni ɪz nəʊ ˈɒbdʒɪktǁ-ˈɑːb-/ use this to say that you do not care how much money you spend on something even if it is a lot:
examples: tiền không thành vấn đề
▪ Simon always ordered the best. It was obvious that money was no object.
money no object
▪ Choose whatever outfit you want - money no object!

children.name: live the high life
children.definition: /ˌlɪv ðə ˈhaɪ laɪf/  to enjoy yourself by going out often and spending a lot of money, especially withrichorimportantpeople:
examples: sống một cuộc sống thượng lưu
▪ For several years they lived the high life with Hollywood stars and celebrities.
▪ You’ve been living the high life recently, haven’t you! You’re always going out to clubs and fancy restaurants.

children.name: on a shoestring
children.definition: /ɒn ə ˈʃuːstrɪŋ/  if you make a film, run a business etc on a shoestring, you spend verylittlemoney on it, but it is usually asuccess:
examples: dùng rất ít tiền
▪ Nearly all of our research had to be conducted on a shoestring.
▪ The paper started on a shoestring, but soon had a circulation of over 100,000 readers.
shoestring [adjective only before noun]using very little money::
▪ a shoestring budget

children.name: skimp on
children.definition: /ˈskɪmp ɒn/to not spend enough money onimportantmaterials, equipment etc, so that what you are doing or making isunsuccessfulor of bad quality:
examples: hà tiện, bủn xỉn
▪ There’s no point in skimping on essentials such as food and heating.
▪ A company will never get anywhere by skimping on training and technology.

children.name: on the cheap
children.definition: /ɒn ðə ˈtʃiːp/  British if you do or make something on the cheap, you spend as little money as possible on it, so that it is oftenunsuccessfulor of bad quality:
examples: ▪ You only had to look at the houses to see that they’d been built on the cheap.
▪ It’s impossible to provide good nursing care on the cheap.

children.name: sb who spends a lot of money carelessly
extravagant
children.definition: /ɪkˈstrævəgənt/  spending more money than you can afford on expensive things that you do not really need:
examples: tiêu xài phung phí
▪ $400 on a dress! That’s a bit extravagant, isn’t it?
▪ Rich and extravagant parents are spending more and more money on their children’s parties.
extravagantly [adverb]
▪ She put the money in to a savings account so she wasn’t tempted to spend it extravagantly.

children.name: spendthrift
children.definition: /ˈspendˌθrɪft/ formalsomeone who spends money carelessly even when they know that they do cannot afford to:
examples: kẻ hoang phí
▪ I remember him as a charming but irresponsible spendthrift.
▪ She was by no means a spendthrift, but somehow all the money disappeared anyway.

children.name: big spender
children.definition: /ˌbɪg ˈspendəʳ/  a rich person who spends a lot of money, especially in order toimpressother people:
examples: Kẻ hoang phí
▪ I didn’t trust him at all. He was a big spender, that’s all.
▪ This is the time of year when all the big spenders pour into Las Vegas hotels and casinos.

children.name: cut back/down
children.definition: phrasal verb cắt bớt
examples: to do less of something or use something in smaller amounts
_The government has announced plans to to cut backondefence spending by 10% next year.
_I'm trying to cut downoncaffeine.

children.name: cut down
children.definition: /ˌkʌt ˈdaʊn/  to reduce the amount of money that you regularly spend:
examples: cắt giảm ( chi phí )
▪ We’ve had to cut down a lot since Craig lost his job - it’s been very hard for us.
cut down on
▪ She’s already cut down on going out and buying clothes, but she doesn’t have enough money to start paying off her debts.
cut down somebody’s expenses/bills etc
▪ The department has overspent this year and we will have to cut down our expenses.

children.name: economize
children.definition: alsoeconomiseBritish /ɪˈkɒnəmaɪzǁɪˈkɑː-/to spend less money by buying only the things that you really need, or by buying cheaper things:
examples: tiếu kiệm chi tiêu
▪ Sorry, I can’t come out tonight - I’m trying to economize.
▪ We’re economizing this year by having a cheaper vacation.
economize onspend less money on something
▪ Families on low incomes are having to economize on food and heating costs.

children.name: scrimp and save
children.definition: /ˌskrɪmp ən ˈseɪv/  to spend as little money as possible, only buying things you really need, because you have very little money and want to save it to use in the future:
examples: chắt chiu tích góp
▪ Chris’s parents scrimped and saved so that he could go to college.
▪ I had hardly any money left and was scrimping and saving just to buy the bare necessities.

children.name: tighten your belt
children.definition: /ˌtaɪtn jɔːʳ ˈbelt/  to spend less money than you usually do because there is less money available:
examples: thắt chặt chi tiêu
▪ Most people have to tighten their belts a little when they retire
▪ Governments and companies are forced to tighten their belts during a recession.

children.name: to spend money quickly or carelessly
squander
children.definition: /ˈskwɒndəʳǁˈskwɑːn-/  to spend all the money you have onunnecessarythings instead of saving it or using it carefully:
examples: ▪ In less than three years he had squandered the entire family fortune.
▪ There was no money to pay the rent. They’d already squandered the little that they had.
squander on
▪ Here’s £50 but don’t just go and squander it on beer!

children.name: blow
children.definition: /bləʊ/ informalto spend a lot of money on something expensive and enjoyable, especially something that you do not really need:
examples: phung phí ( tiền bạc )
blow £50/$100 etc on something
▪ We blew $3000 on a trip to Barbados.
blow it all/blow the lotBritish spend everything
▪ He won £500,000 in the National Lottery, but he’s already blown the lot.

children.name: go through
children.definition: alsoget through somethingBritish /ˌgəʊ ˈθruː, ˌget ˈθruː something/  to spend the money that you have morequicklythan expected, so that you havenothing left:
examples: tiêu hết , xài hết
▪ I got through all of my money in less than a month and had to get my parents to send me more.
go through £100/$2000 etc
▪ The hotel was really expensive. We went through $3000 in the first week.

children.name: spend money like water U
children.definition: spend money like water/like there’s no tomorrow /spend ˌmʌni laɪk ˈwɔːtəʳ, laɪk ðeəʳz ˌnəʊ təˈmɒrəʊǁ-ˈmɔː-/  informal to spend a lot of money very quickly and carelessly without worrying how much you are spending or how long your money will last:
examples: tiêu tiền như nước
▪ Richard spends money like there’s no tomorrow! Where does he get it all from?
▪ I don’t trust myself with a credit card - I spend money like water as it is.

children.name: on
children.definition: prepositionMONEY
examples: used to showsomethingfor which a payment is made
_He spent eighty poundsona hat.
_I've wasted a lot of moneyonthis car.
_We made a big profitonthat deal.
_How much interest are you payingonthe loan?
